stories.title: Where Carnival Began
stories.core_insight: The original Mardi Gras was Carnival Cruise Line's first ship, launching the company in 1972
stories.markdown:
**TSS Mardi Gras launched Carnival Cruise Line in 1972—the ship that started what would become the world's largest cruise company.**

Ted Arison founded Carnival with this converted Canadian Pacific ocean liner, originally named Empress of Canada. The ship's transformation into Mardi Gras marked the beginning of the 'Fun Ships' revolution.

The inaugural voyage on March 11, 1972, was inauspicious—the ship ran aground leaving Miami. But Carnival recovered, refined its approach, and built success from this unlikely beginning.

Mardi Gras introduced the casual, party-focused cruising that would define Carnival. The ship served Caribbean routes from Miami, targeting first-time cruisers seeking fun rather than formality.

For company origin: Mardi Gras was where Carnival began. Every ship in the current fleet traces its heritage to this converted ocean liner and the vision she represented.

stories.title: A Rocky Start
stories.core_insight: Mardi Gras's troubled debut nearly ended Carnival before it began
stories.markdown:
**TSS Mardi Gras's inaugural voyage included grounding on a sandbar—a troubled start that nearly ended Carnival's story before it began.**

The grounding made headlines and damaged credibility. Early months brought financial struggles as the new company found its footing. Carnival's survival was uncertain.

But Ted Arison and his team persevered. They refined the Fun Ships concept, adjusted pricing, improved marketing, and built the party atmosphere that would attract passengers.

Mardi Gras gradually found success. The ship's Caribbean cruises attracted travelers who had never cruised before. The accessible pricing and casual atmosphere proved appealing.

For survival story: Mardi Gras's troubled start makes Carnival's eventual dominance more remarkable. The company that nearly failed with one grounded ship now operates the world's largest cruise fleet.

stories.title: The Fun Ships Revolution
stories.intended_reader: Those interested in cruise industry evolution
stories.core_insight: Mardi Gras pioneered the accessible, entertainment-focused cruising that transformed the industry
stories.markdown:
**TSS Mardi Gras pioneered the Fun Ships approach that would transform cruising from elite pastime to mass-market vacation option.**

Traditional cruise lines emphasized formality, tradition, and exclusivity. Carnival's Mardi Gras offered something different: casual atmosphere, affordable pricing, and entertainment-focused experience.

The ship featured nightclub-style entertainment, casual dining, and party atmosphere that attracted younger, less wealthy passengers than traditional lines served.

The approach worked. Passengers who had never considered cruising discovered ocean vacations through Mardi Gras. The market expanded dramatically as Carnival proved cruising could be fun and accessible.

For industry impact: Mardi Gras started a revolution. The ship proved that cruising could serve everyone—not just the wealthy and formal. That insight built the modern cruise industry.
